Roosevelt first introduced Stalin to the idea of an international organization comprising all nation states, a venue for the resolution of common issues, and a check against international aggressors. The UN was a prioity for the FDR Admin as a replacement for Wilson's failed League of Nations which the 1919 US Senate refused to approve the Treaty of Versailles. With FDRs death it was up to Truman to make the policy happen. The charter took effect on 24 October 1945, when the UN began operations. At its founding, the UN had 51 member states; as of 2023, it has 193.

It seems that many Americans have no idea how the UN Security Council works.  Here's a brief refresher.  At the end of WWII the UN was founded.   In broadest terms there are two parts of the UN, the UN General Assembly and the UN Security Council.  
Everything important gets handled by the Security Council.  In the Security Council there are the 5 Great Powers comprised of the US, Great Britain, France, Russia (USSR), and China.  These are also known as the 5 permanent members.  There are also 10 non-permanent members being held on a rotating basis.  Any one of the 5 permanent members can veto any Security Council resolution.  
In the case of the recent vote regarding aid to Hamas (Gaza), the US by abstaining to vote effectively voted 'Yes' in support of UN funding for Hamas.
